questions.text: Which of the following statements about the basal ganglia and their associated neurotransmitters is CORRECT?

choices.text: The caudate nucleus primarily uses acetylcholine as its neurotransmitter.
The globus pallidus internus (GPi) exerts an excitatory influence on the thalamus.
The subthalamic nucleus (STN) uses glutamate as its principal neurotransmitter to excite the globus pallidus internus (GPi).
The substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr) inhibits the thalamus using dopamine.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The subthalamic nucleus (STN) uses glutamate as its principal neurotransmitter to excite the globus pallidus internus (GPi).

 

Explanation:

The subthalamic nucleus (STN) uses glutamate to excite the GPi.

 

The basal ganglia are a group of subcortical nuclei in the brain involved in regulating movement and coordinating motor activity. Key parts include:

  • Striatum: Consists of the caudate nucleus and putamen. It's the main input center for the basal ganglia, receiving information from the cerebral cortex.
  • Globus Pallidus: Divided into the external (GPe) and internal (GPi) segments. It plays a role in the regulation of voluntary movement by processing signals from the striatum.
  • Substantia Nigra: Located in the midbrain and has two parts: the pars compacta (which produces dopamine) and the pars reticulata. It is involved in movement control and has a key role in the dopamine system.
  • Subthalamic Nucleus: Located below the thalamus, it contributes to motor control by influencing the output of the globus pallidus.

 

The basal ganglia use several key neurotransmitters to regulate motor control:

  1. Dopamine: Produced by the substantia nigra, particularly the pars compacta.
  2. GABA (Gamma-Aminobutyric Acid): The primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the basal ganglia. It is released by neurons in the striatum, globus pallidus (both external and internal segments), and substantia nigra (pars reticulata).
  3. Glutamate: The primary excitatory neurotransmitter. It is released by the cerebral cortex to the striatum and by the subthalamic nucleus to the globus pallidus and substantia nigra.


 

  • The caudate nucleus primarily uses GABA as its neurotransmitter, not acetylcholine. (Option A)
  • The globus pallidus internus (GPi) exerts an inhibitory influence on the thalamus. (Option B)
  • The substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr) inhibits the thalamus using GABA, not dopamine. (Option D)

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes the effect of each basal ganglia pathway?

choices.text: The direct pathway decreases inhibitory output from the internal segment of the globus pallidus.
The indirect pathway decreases inhibitory output from the internal segment of the globus pallidus.
The direct pathway increases inhibitory output from the external segment of the globus pallidus.
The indirect pathway increases inhibitory output from the external segment of the globus pallidus.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The direct pathway decreases inhibitory output from the internal segment of the globus pallidus.

Explanation:

The basal ganglia play a crucial role in regulating motor control, movement coordination, and certain aspects of cognition.

Direct Pathway:

  • Promotes movement by reducing inhibitory output from the GPi to the thalamus.
  • Mechanism: The striatum inhibits the GPi, leading to less inhibition of the thalamus and increased motor activity.

Indirect Pathway:

  • Inhibits movement by increasing inhibitory output from the GPe to the thalamus.
  • Mechanism: The striatum inhibits the GPe, resulting in less inhibition of the STN, which then excites the GPi. This increased activity of the GPi leads to more inhibition of the thalamus and decreased motor activity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with resting tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability. His symptoms have progressively worsened over the past year. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely underlying pathology?

choices.text: Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta
Degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the basal forebrain
Degeneration of GABAergic neurons in the striatum
Degeneration of serotonergic neurons in the raphe nuclei

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms are characteristic of Parkinson's disease, which is primarily caused by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta.
  • This leads to a decrease in dopamine levels in the striatum, affecting the basal ganglia circuitry and resulting in the hallmark motor symptoms of the disease.
  • Disorders affecting the basal ganglia can result in a range of motor symptoms, leading to either reduced (hypokinetic) or excessive (hyperkinetic) movement.

Hypokinetic Diseases

  • Parkinsonism:
    • Cause: Reduced dopamine in the substantia nigra.
    • Symptoms: Akinesia, bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity, resting tremor, shuffling gait, stooped posture, reduced facial expression, small handwriting, and mood/cognitive issues.

Hyperkinetic Diseases

  • Hemiballismus:
    • Damage to the subthalamic nucleus, leading to decreased inhibition of the thalamus and excessive movement.
  • Huntington's Disease:
    • Degeneration of the indirect pathway in the striatum, causing involuntary movements similar to hemiballismus.
  • Dystonia:
    • Dysfunction in the direct pathway, resulting in sustained, twisting movements.


Degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the basal forebrain is associated with Alzheimer's disease, which primarily affects memory and cognitive functions rather than motor control. (Option B)

 

GABAergic neurons in the striatum are involved in the motor control pathways, but their degeneration is more characteristic of Huntington’s disease which involves a different pattern of motor dysfunction, including chorea, which is not consistent with the symptoms described. (Option C)

 

Degeneration of serotonergic neurons in the raphe nuclei is related to mood disorders and certain types of depression, rather than the motor symptoms seen in Parkinson’s disease. (Option D)

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes the cerebellar structure and its nuclei?

choices.text: Anterior and posterior lobes regulate posture and balance
Flocculonodular lobe coordinates fine motor skills.
Dentate nucleus is key in motor planning and execution.
Granule cells are the primary output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dentate nucleus is key in motor planning and execution

 

Explanation:

Overview of the anatomy of the cerebellum, including its lobes, lobules, cortex, and nuclei:

  • Lobes:
    • Anterior Lobe: Located superiorly and anteriorly, it is involved in the coordination of voluntary movements and posture.
    • Posterior Lobe: Positioned between the primary fissure and the posterior cerebellar notch, it plays a crucial role in the planning and execution of complex movements.
    • Flocculonodular Lobe: Located at the inferior part of the cerebellum, it is crucial for maintaining balance and coordinating eye movements.
  • Lobules:
    • The cerebellum is divided into lobules by fissures. Major lobules include:
      • Lobule I–V: Part of the anterior lobe.
      • Lobule VI–VII: Part of the posterior lobe.
      • Lobule VIII–IX: Located in the posterior lobe and flocculonodular lobe.
  • Cortex:
    • The cerebellar cortex is organized into three layers:
      • Molecular Layer: Contains the dendritic trees of Purkinje cells and interneurons like stellate and basket cells.
      • Purkinje Cell Layer: Contains Purkinje cells, which are the primary output neurons of the cerebellar cortex, sending inhibitory signals to the deep cerebellar nuclei.
      • Granular Layer: Contains granule cells, which receive input from the mossy fibers and send excitatory projections to the Purkinje cells.
  • Nuclei:
    • The deep cerebellar nuclei are the primary output nuclei of the cerebellum and include dentate nucleus, emboliform nucleus, globose nucleus, and fastigial nucleus.

 

The anterior and posterior lobes of the cerebellum are primarily involved in the coordination of voluntary movements and fine motor control. Posture and balance are more closely associated with the flocculonodular lobe and its connections. (Option A)

 

The cerebellum is actually divided into three main lobes: the anterior, posterior, and flocculonodular lobes. The flocculonodular lobe primarily contributes to balance and eye movements rather than fine motor skills. (Option B)

 

Granule cells in the cerebellar cortex are not the primary output neurons. Instead, Purkinje cells are the main output neurons, sending inhibitory signals to the deep cerebellar nuclei. Granule cells send excitatory input to Purkinje cells. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the primary function of the mossy fibers in the internal circuitry of the cerebellum?

choices.text: Transmit motor commands to the cerebellum
Provide excitatory input to granule cells.
Relay sensory information to the deep cerebellar nuclei.
inhibit the activity of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Provide excitatory input to granule cells

 

Explanation:

  • Mossy fibers provide excitatory input to the granule cells in the cerebellar cortex. Granule cells, in turn, project their axons as parallel fibers, which make excitatory synapses on the Purkinje cells.
  • The following components of the cerebellar internal circuit integrate sensory and motor information to fine-tune motor activities and support motor learning.
  1. Mossy Fibers: These are the primary excitatory inputs to the cerebellum, originating from various brainstem nuclei and the spinal cord. They convey sensory and motor-related information to the cerebellar cortex.
  2. Granule Cells: Mossy fibers synapse onto granule cells, the most numerous neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Granule cells receive excitatory input from mossy fibers and then extend their axons as parallel fibers across the cerebellar cortex.
  3. Purkinje Cells: Granule cell parallel fibers synapse onto Purkinje cells, which are large inhibitory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Purkinje cells play a key role in modulating the output from the cerebellum.
  4. Deep Cerebellar Nuclei: Purkinje cells send inhibitory signals to the deep cerebellar nuclei, which are the primary output structures of the cerebellum. These nuclei project to various motor centers in the brainstem and thalamus, influencing motor coordination and timing.
  5. Climbing Fibers: These originate from the inferior olive and provide a powerful excitatory input directly to Purkinje cells. Climbing fibers are involved in error correction during motor learning by adjusting the strength of synaptic connections between granule cells and Purkinje cells.

 

  • Mossy fibers do not directly transmit motor commands from the cerebral cortex.
  • They carry sensory and other inputs to the cerebellum, which then processes and integrates these inputs to help coordinate motor commands. (Option A)

 

  • Mossy fibers do not relay sensory information directly to the deep cerebellar nuclei.
  • They first synapse in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex. From there, the processed information is relayed to the deep cerebellar nuclei via Purkinje cells. (Option C)

 

  • Inhibitory control of the deep cerebellar nuclei is primarily mediated by Purkinje cells, which send inhibitory signals to the deep cerebellar nuclei.
  • Mossy fibers provide excitatory input to the cerebellar cortex, which indirectly influences the activity of the deep nuclei. (Option D)

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with uncoordinated movements and difficulty in performing rapid alternating tasks, speech difficulty, and experiences rapid, tremulous eye movements. Which of the following features is not typically associated with cerebellar disease?

choices.text: Hypertonia
Dysarthria
Ataxia
Rebound Phenomenon

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypertonia

Explanation:
Hypotonia is a characteristic of cerebellar diseases, not hypertonia. It occurs on the same side as the cerebellar lesion.

Clinical Features of Cerebellar Diseases

Hypotonia

Decreased muscle tone, often on the same side as the cerebellar lesion.

Ataxia (Option C)

Uncoordinated movements, often leading to a "drunken" gait.

Dysdiadochokinesia

Inability to perform rapid alternating movements, such as flipping the hands back and forth.

Dysmetria (Past pointing)

Movements that overshoot or undershoot the intended target.

Intention tremor

Tremors occurring when moving toward a target

Dysarthria (Option B)

Jumbled speech due to lack of coordination in the muscles involved in speech

Nystagmus

Rapid, tremulous eye movements

Rebound Phenomenon (Option D)

Limb jerking back after resistance is suddenly removed

Decomposition of movement

Can't move multiple joints simultaneously.

No sensory deficit

Not typically present in cerebellar diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the amygdala is incorrect?

choices.text: Controls emotions and motivations
Connected with the prefrontal cortex & hippocampus for emotional memory processing
Damage can result in a loss of sexual behaviour.
The prefrontal cortex develops working memory

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Damage can result in a loss of sexual behaviour.

Explanation:

  • Damage to the amygdala typically results in hypersexuality, not a loss of sexual behavior, as seen in Kluver-Bucy syndrome.

  • Amygdala is part of limbic system central, controlling emotions and motivations. It is connected with the prefrontal cortex & hippocampus via amygdala circuitry for the acquisition, consolidation, and retrieval of memories associated with emotions. (Option A and B)

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. He displays significant behavioral changes including placing non-food objects in his mouth, increased sexual advances towards staff, and appears to have no fear when approached by the medical team. Which of the following brain structures is MOST likely to be damaged in this patient?

choices.text: Cerebellum
Amygdala
Hippocampus
Parietal lobe

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Amygdala

 

Explanation:

The case presents a patient with classic symptoms of Klüver-Bucy syndrome, including a lack of fear, oral tendencies, and hypersexuality.

  • It is a rare behavioral disorder that can occur after damage to the anterior temporal lobes, including the amygdalae, which are almond-shaped groups of nuclei located deep within the temporal lobes.
  • The amygdala is responsible for processing emotions, especially fear and reward.

The symptoms of Klüver-Bucy syndrome are varied but can include the following:

  • Lack of Fear: Individuals may show no fear of objects or situations that would normally elicit a fear response.
  • Excessive Curiosity: They may display an intense interest in exploring their surroundings, often in a non-directed and inappropriate manner.
  • Memory Impairment: Short-term memory is often significantly affected, leading to an inability to recall recent events.
  • Oral Tendencies: A tendency to put objects in their mouth, even those that are not edible.
  • Hypersexuality: An increased and often inappropriate sexual drive.

 

Cerebellum (Option A): Responsible for motor coordination and balance. Damage → ataxia, dysmetria, intention tremor. Does not cause behavioral symptoms like hypersexuality or hyperorality.

Hippocampus (Option C): Critical for forming new memories. Damage → anterograde amnesia. Does not cause hypersexuality or placidity.

Parietal lobe (Option D): Involved in spatial awareness, sensory integration, and body awareness. Damage can cause hemineglect, apraxia, or Gerstmann syndrome. Behavioral disinhibition is not typical.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with significant behavioral changes following a traumatic brain injury. He experiences frequent unprovoked outbursts of anger and aggression, triggered by minimal stimuli, along with emotional blunting and decreased pleasure. Based on his presentation, which brain region is MOST likely affected?

choices.text: Hippocampus
Medial forebrain bundle
Central gray area
Ventromedial hypothalamus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ventromedial hypothalamus

 

Explanation:

The ventromedial hypothalamus plays a crucial role in inhibiting rage responses generated by other parts of the limbic system, such as the periventricular zone and lateral hypothalamus. Damage to the ventromedial hypothalamus can lead to disinhibition of these rage centers, resulting in the aggressive behavior exhibited by the patient. Additionally, the ventromedial hypothalamus is involved in promoting feelings of satiety and tranquility, while damage to this area can lead to overeating and hyperactivity.

Medial forebrain bundle (Option B)– Associated with reward and motivation, not directly responsible for aggressive outbursts.

questions.text: In a patient experiencing severe hemorrhage resulting in isotonic fluid loss, which of the following accurately describes the role of osmoreceptors and their effect on the thirst mechanism?

choices.text: Increased blood osmolality stimulates the supra-optic nucleus to secrete ADH
Angiotensin II indirectly stimulates the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus
Osmoreceptors in the OVLT and MnPO are stimulated by decreased blood osmolality
Stimulated SFO osmoreceptors increase ANP secretion, which reduces ADH.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Angiotensin II  indirectly stimulates the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus

 

Explanation:

 

The hypothalamus primarily regulates the thirst mechanism, and the lateral nucleus houses the thirst centre.

  • The osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus
    • These three osmoreceptors Median Preoptic Nucleus (MnPO), Organum Vasculosum Laminae Terminalis (OVLT), and Sub Fornical Nucleus (SFO) play key roles in detecting changes in blood osmolality or sodium ion concentration.
    • An increase in blood osmolality or sodium ions stimulates the OVLT, which then activates MnPO through interconnected pathways. It does not directly stimulate the supra-optic nucleus (Option A)

 

  • Response to isotonic loss of fluid (e.g. severe haemorrhage)
    • Severe hemorrhage results in isotonic fluid loss from the blood, triggering an increase in renin secretion.
    • Renin secretion leads to elevated levels of angiotensin 2 (Ag II), which acts as a stimulus for the SFO.
    • Despite the blood osmolality remaining constant during haemorrhage, the SFO can still be stimulated by the presence of angiotensin 2. (Option B)

 

  • Pathways of signals
    • Signals from stimulated osmoreceptors primarily target two brain regions:
      • Lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus, stimulating thirst and causing the person to feel thirsty.
      • Supra-optic nucleus of the hypothalamus, which produces ADH (antidiuretic hormone).
    • ADH acts on the kidneys to reabsorb water, thereby reducing osmolality or sodium ion concentration in the body.

 

Stimulated osmoreceptors in the SFO increase the secretion of ADH. (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the control of feeding?

choices.text: Both orexigenic and anorexigenic signals are present in the pre-ventricular nucleus
Leptin, Peptide YY and CCK are all orexigenic signals
POMC Fragmentation produces alpha MSH promotes food intake
Orexin peptide produced from the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus plays an essential role in regulating sleep

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Orexin peptide produced from the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus plays an essential role in regulating sleep

 

Explanation:

Orexin peptide produced from the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus plays an essential role in regulating sleep and also increases food intake.

 

Theory of control of feeding:

 

Arcuate Nucleus Overview:

  • Located in the hypothalamus, it integrates orexigenic and anorexigenic signals to regulate feeding behaviour. (Option A)

Neuronal Types:

  • POMC Neurons:
    • Produce alpha-MSH, an anorexigenic signal that reduces food intake. (Option C)
  • NPY and AGRP Neurons:
    • Produce orexigenic signals that stimulate the hypothalamic pre-ventricular nucleus, increasing food intake.

Peripheral Signals:

  • Anorexigenic Signals (reduce food intake):
    • Insulin, leptin, CCK, and Peptide YY stimulate POMC neurons. (Option B)
  • Orexigenic Signals (increase food intake):
    • Ghrelin and cortisol stimulate NPY and AGRP neurons.

Leptin and Obesity:

  • Leptin, indicating fat cell mass, acts as an anorexigenic signal in the hypothalamus.
  • High leptin levels in obese individuals indicate a large fat cell mass, promoting reduced food intake.

Role of Orexin:

  • Produced by the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus, orexin regulates sleep and increases food intake.

questions.text: Which statement best describes the center-surround model of the basal ganglia?

choices.text: The direct pathway broadly inhibits motor actions, while the indirect pathway facilitates specific actions.
The direct pathway facilitates specific motor actions, while the indirect pathway suppresses competing actions.
The indirect pathway reduces inhibitory output from the GPi, while the direct pathway increases inhibitory output.
Both pathways uniformly facilitate all motor actions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The direct pathway facilitates specific motor actions, while the indirect pathway suppresses competing actions.

 

Explanation:

Center-Surround Model:

The centre-surround model describes how the basal ganglia circuitry provides focused activation (centre) while suppressing surrounding activity (surround) to enhance motor control and precision.

  • Centre: The direct pathway acts as a "centre" mechanism by facilitating specific motor actions and enhancing desired movements. It reduces inhibitory signals from the GPi/SNr to the thalamus, thereby increasing thalamic activity related to the motor cortex.
  • Surround: The indirect pathway acts as a "surround" mechanism by inhibiting unwanted movements and refining motor control. It increases inhibition in broader motor regions by enhancing the inhibition of the GPi/SNr, thus decreasing thalamic activation.

 

 

 

  • The direct pathway does not broadly inhibit motor actions; it facilitates specific actions by reducing inhibition from the GPi. The indirect pathway does not facilitate actions; it suppresses competing actions by increasing inhibition. (Option A)
  • The indirect pathway increases inhibitory output from the GPi, not reduces it. The direct pathway reduces inhibitory output from the GPi. (Option C)
  • The pathways do not uniformly facilitate all motor actions. (Option D)
